comment.author: 25695066@N00
comment._content: This is the Prospect Hill Reservoir. This property would later become Mount Prospect Park. This view is on Flatbush Avenue looking to the north toward the southwest side of the reservoir. Here's a Google Maps link approximating the postion of the photographer of this photograph. maps.google.com/maps?q=(40.669929843442304,+-73.967406749... Another perspective: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/brooklyn_museum/5833480662/in/photostream]

comment.author: 83979593@N00
comment._content: On June 23, 2011, TVL1970 suggested where this photo was taken; thank you for your efforts to #mapBK!

comment.author: 83979593@N00
comment._content:
Hi TVL1970! Thanks for all your help with this project! I tweaked the Google maps coordinates a tiny bit in Suggestify, which gives you the ability to be a bit more precise (give it a try!). The Google lat/long showed up in the middle of Flatbush Avenue, so I moved the location into the edge of Mount Prospect Park. 
Thanks again,
Deb Wythe
Digital Lab

comment.author: 25695066@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/brooklyn_museum] 
Thanks Deb, 
  This is a great project.  I appreciate the help.  It's been a bit of a headache trying to tweak the Google Maps GPS coordinates to the actual point(s) I have chosen.   Frequently in using Google Maps the coordinates seem to vary from the point chosen by approximately 50-100 yards at time.  If the coordinates can be made even more precise, all the better.

comment.author: 54135313@N05
comment._content: I had no idea that there was a Reservoir located here. I wonder how much the terrain was changed around the "Battle Pass" area from 1776-2011?. robertgouldhistoricalartist.blogspot.com/

comment.author: 83979593@N00
comment._content:
Hi Rob,
Once this project is done, you may be able to zero in on multiple images from that area -- there are lots of photos of Brooklyn's countryside from the turn of the 20th century in the collection. Stay tuned (and feel free to geotag any you find in the mysteries set from the #mapBK project!)

Very interesting blog! Hope you find grist for your painting mill among our images!

Deb Wythe
Digital Lab
